Targeting Child Predators Act of 2017
Targeting Child Predators Act of 2017

To amend title 18, United States Code, to provide a certification process for the issuance of nondisclosure requirements accompanying certain administrative subpoenas, to provide for judicial review of such nondisclosure requirements, and for other purposes.
Targeting Child Predators Act of 2017

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.
Referred to the Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism, Homeland Security, and Investigations.

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported by Voice Vote.

action.text: Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Reported by the Committee on Judiciary. H. Rept. 115-141.

calendar.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 90.

action.text: Mr. Goodlatte moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 883.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

committee.subcommittee: Crime, Terrorism, Homeland Security, and Investigations
committee.name: House Judiciary

bill.summary:
Targeting Child Predators Act of 2017
This bill amends the federal criminal code to revise provisions with respect to a nondisclosure requirement issued in connection with certain administrative subpoenas (e.g., an administrative subpoena in a child exploitation and abuse investigation).
The bill modifies the process for issuing a nondisclosure requirement and lengthens the period of time during which a recipient of an administrative subpoena is prohibited from disclosure.
It also subjects a nondisclosure requirement to judicial review, requires the administrative subpoena to include notice of the availability of judicial review, and establishes a process for judicial review.
